column1: Fusagasugá (Spanish pronunciation: [fusaɣasuˈɣa]; from cariban  fusagasuga 'Woman who becomes invisible (Mujer que se hace invisible)') or Fusa is a town and municipality in the department of Cundinamarca
column2: in central Colombia.  It is located in the warm valley between the rivers Cuja and Panches
column3: a central region of the Andes Mountains in South America.  The municipality has an estimated population of 134
column4: 523 as of 2015. The urban region has 108
column5: 157 inhabitants. The municipality itself covers an area of 206 km2 (80 sq mi).It was founded in 1592 by Spanish priests. The town located some 56 kilometers from the capital
column6: Bogotá; borders Pasca

column1: The interpretation of the name in Spanish varies from "Mujer que se hace invisible" (Woman who becomes invisible) to "Mujer que se esconde tras la montaña" (Woman who hides herself behind the mountain).  However

column1: The city has been named "Tierra Grata" due to the farms (Quintas) located on its territory. And commonly is called The Garden City of Colombia ("La Ciudad Jardín de Colombia") by the production of Orchids.

The Sutagao people inhabited the region until the new town was founded by Oídor Bernardino Albornoz between 5–13 February 1592.  Not much is known about the previous indigenous residents. During the visit of Oídor Ibarra
column2: there were 759 indigenous people residing in Fusagasugá. When Oídor Aróstequi arrived in February 1760
column3: the indigenous population had dwindled to 85
column4: and there were 644 new settlers divided among 109 families. On February 19
column6: a small hospital was established near the church and Father Vicente de Fresneda was given charge of it.

column1: In 2007 the municipality ranked the tenth place on department according to its economy. The GDP estimated at 2007 is $544
column2: 984 million. The majority of the regional economy is made up of agriculture and construction services. Aside from these sectors
column3: there has been rapid growth in the service industry because of the strengthening in the sectors of education
column6: and tourism. Local government policies to support agrotechnology have fostered short-term
column7: local development. The municipality has nowadays the third category.
